overview: Beginning January 1, 2026, this bill requires pharmacy technicians to be registered. [1] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. [1] The bill also specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [1]
appropriations: This measure does not contain any specific appropriations. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: This bill does not provide a methodology for calculating its fiscal impact. [1] It establishes a biennial registration fee for pharmacy technicians, which shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] The bill also establishes fines for violations. [1]
agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy will be required to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [1] The board is authorized to fine, suspend, or revoke any registration or permit for any cause prescribed by this chapter. [1] Additionally, the pharmacist-in-charge is required to notify the board of any suspected violations by a registered pharmacy technician. [1]
economic_impact: The bill establishes a registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant to this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1] No other economic impacts, such as cost savings, are mentioned in the bill. [1]
policy_impact: This Act amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by requiring pharmacy technicians to obtain a valid registration beginning January 1, 2026. [1] It specifies that the supervising registered pharmacist shall be responsible for the actions of the registered pharmacy technician. [1] The bill also permits a registered pharmacy technician under the direct supervision of a registered pharmacist to administer a vaccine to a person three years of age or older, subject to certain training and certification requirements. [1]
revenue_sources: Revenue will be generated from a registration fee for a pharmacy technician, which shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Additional revenue may come from disciplinary fines, as any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [1] Beginning January 1, 2026, no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid registration issued by the board. [1] Each registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, at which point a new registration shall be required. [1] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] This will create a recurring biennial revenue stream for the state. [1] The bill also allows for fines of not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation, which may generate additional, albeit unpredictable, revenue. [1] The Board of Pharmacy will incur administrative costs to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [1] The board may also incur costs related to disciplinary actions, including proceedings for denial, suspension, fine, or revocation of a registration. [1] No specific appropriations for these administrative costs are provided in the measure. [1]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure is expected to increase operating revenue for the state. [1] The primary source of new revenue will be the registration fee for a pharmacy technician, which shall be $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt). [1] Additional operating revenue may be generated from fines for violations, which shall be not less than $100.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1]
capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not specify any capital expenditures related to this measure. [1] There is no mention of investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure. [1]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The fiscal implications of this measure are expected to be ongoing. [1] The biennial registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_.HTM.txt) will continue to generate recurring revenue for the state. [1] Administrative costs for the Board of Pharmacy to manage registrations and disciplinary actions will persist beyond the initial six-year period. [1]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [1]
